ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Hey, Wall, and we learned that the boy wanted to make his neighborhood beautiful again just like he grandma Addy remembers. He worked with people in his neighborhood to make the neighborhood beautiful.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of people doing different things to help their neighborhood stay beautiful. We will say how this would help them care for the neighborhood.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Caring for a Neighborhood Invite children to talk about the different ways people took care of their neighborhoods in today’s activity. Encourage children to use as many describingwords as possible as they talk about what they learned.

For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Then, ask children to tell what else they see in the picture. Encourage as much conversation as possible.

Encourage children to participate in peer-to-peer conversations about each card, with each child taking two turns in the conversation. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other is listening. The talker should hold the card as a reminder of this.

Model and encourage children to use a physical response, in addition to speaking, to talk about what the people in the pictures are doing. For example, they can pretend to pick up trash or plant flowers.

Many children may have difficulty staying seated during large- or small-group activities. These children may be tired, but they may also need input for their sensory system. If children have trouble sitting still or listening during lessons, you might want to try distributing hand fidgets or other manipulatives such as a stress ball or bouncy bands. Set fidget rules for the classroom.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In the book Hey, Wall, we focused on flexible thinking and behavior. We learned that the boy thought the wall was cold and empty, but later he saw it as a way that he and the neighbors could make the neighborhood beautiful again.
When we show flexible thinking and behavior, we change what we normally think or do in response to a new situation, a new event, or new information.
In this activity, you will look at the same picture on different cards and try to see the picture in a different way every time we look at it because of the new information I will give to you.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Flexible Thinking Talk together about how we can all look at the same thing and see it in a different way or see different things every time we look at it. Ask children if it was hard to see the picture in different ways. Encourage conversation, especially around any instances where a child changed his or her mind about what they saw.
For children who have a hard time identifying what they see based on the information you give, ask them what they see (e.g., boys, girls, colors).
Invite children to come up with two different ways of seeing a picture based on the information you give them. Encourage children to use describing words to talk about what they see.

Children whose first language is Spanish will recognize the Spanish cognate idea for the English word idea. Explain that the word is spelled the same in English and in Spanish. Making these language connections will free children’s minds for the important flexible thinking they will do in this game.

Children often learn the sounds for p, m, and w earlier than sounds like z, v, or th. By the age of four, most children can pronounce all of the speech sounds, although some four-year-old children will still have problems with the sounds s, sh, ch, j, ng, th, z, l, and r. By age three, familiar people should understand what children are saying, and by age four most people should understand a child’s speech. Provide safe opportunities for children to practice sounds in different words and longer sentences.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need the book Hey, Wall.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Hey, Wall. We saw the characters in the book doing many different activities around the neighborhood. Today, we will act out some of those activities.
In this activity, we will look at some pictures from the book Hey, Wall. Then I will ask you to act out the activity you see.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model Show the picture on page 6, where the boy and his friend James are riding their skateboards. Have children pretend they are riding skateboards, too. Remind them to put on their helmets!

Act It Out Show children the following pages in Hey, Wall and encourage them to act out what is happening: page 7: Danny and her friends building snowmen; page 8: Grandma Addy showing the boy pictures from her photo album; page 9: The children eating ice cream cones; page 10: The children cheering for tiny flowers to push through the cracks in the sidewalk; page 13: The neighbors eating together, sharing stories, and belly laughing; page 14: The neighbors dancing and spinning; and page 22: The neighbors staring down the wall.

Talk About Neighborhoods Invite children to talk about their own neighborhood and neighbors, using as many describing words as possible. Encourage children to share all the fun things they see and do in their neighborhoods.

Review each picture and necessary vocabulary and concepts with the large group. Help children learn to respond in complete sentences by modeling a complete sentence and asking children to repeat it after you.

Have children talk about and act out what they have done in their neighborhoods. Encourage them to use regular past tense and possessive pronoun. Model the first example by talking and acting out something you do in your neighborhood.

Some who were not born in the United States, or in states with only warm weather, may not be familiar with building a snowman. Some children may not be familiar with an ice cream truck. Many of the children may not be familiar with growing up in a city like the one in the story. Show children pictures of different city neighborhoods.

Dramatic play can help gross motor development, which involves thought and deliberate movement. Participate with children to model for them different movements. Demonstrate how they can act these activities out with each other, as each of these activities shows what the neighbors did with each other.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we looked at the poster Our Neighborhood, and we learned about different places in the neighborhood. We saw what different people do there.
In this activity, we will look at some pictures of children in different places in their neighborhoods and then try to guess where they are.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model Show the first card of a boy in class and ask the question. If children respond “in class,” praise them for the correct answer. Then say the complete sentence, “The boy is in class.” Ask the children to repeat the sentence after you. The object of this activity is to practice subject-verb agreement. Also, it will help children be aware of where they are in relation to others, and remind them to respect others’ boundaries.
Ask Show one picture and ask the question on the back, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About It You can practice the past tense of the verb “to be” and subject-verb agreement by discussing each card in the past tense. For example: Where was the boy, in class or at home? Where was the family, on the playground or at the park?
For children who cannot identify where the person in the picture is, have them describe everything they see in the picture. Calling out details might help children guess where the person is.
Have children answer in complete sentences. They can use sentences such as: “The girl is on the bus. The boy is at the beach. The family is at the park.”

Humans learn the grammar of language through oral language models. Subject-verb agreement is an abstract concept even for older children. It helps to lay a good foundation for children to learn the grammar of academic language during these early years. If a child says something incorrectly, such as “They was singing,” respond by repeating the statement correctly, such as “Yes. They were singing.”

Create a sensory-friendly classroom by providing accommodations for children who have difficulty remaining still during activities that require attention without movement. You may have children stand after each question and raise both hands, clap their hands, or some other movement to help them “take a break” between cards.
